content:
‚úÖ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Very nice puzzle and test cases, good job! My only remark is that I think this puzzle should have been in Medium because the scoring system is a little confusing and never having played Scrabble, I had to go to wikipedia to understand the rules.

‚úÖ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Great puzzle. The description is clear and well followed by the tests. Everything seems covered, and the difficulty is suitable üëç

‚úÖ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Fun easy puzzle, description is easy to understand and test cases are covering everything.

Hi,

Nice puzzle, I enjoyed solving it.
You are missing the case where 'w' and 'W' are applied to the same word, outside of that it seems that everything is covered.

Here's a case where my code (that atm passes everything) returns a wrong solution. Basically I don't handle duplicate words.

2
A 1
N 1
4 4
W.w.
....
....
....
....
N.N.
A.A.
....
AAA.
N.N.
A.A.
....

I return 

AAA 18
ANA 9
Total 27

But it should at least return 3 words, AAA, ANA, ANA.

I think the easier solution is to say that they are no duplicate words, but if you want to allow it, then you will need to precise in which order to print them also.

Should ANA 3 < ANA 5 ? ANA 10 > ANA 1 ? etc.

And the awful code for reference. Will expire in 1 week but I can delete earlier if you want me to: [link removed]

This is what I got for not knowing how maps work in C.

I'm sorry, how are the multipliers supposed to work?

Let's say I have:
- A word with flat score 10, that contains (at least) two letters: X, with a score of 1, and Y with a score of 2 (and other letters that are not relevant)
- X is over a L tile
- Y is over a w tile

Should the final result be:
(First factor letters)
- ((10 - 1) + 3 * 1) * 2 = 12 * 2 = 24
(First factor words)
- 10 * 2 - 1 + 3 * 1 = 19 + 3 = 22

Also, if I have a word that goes across multiple w, does the multiplier stay 2 for a word, or it becomes 4, 8, 16 etc.

Same question for w and W, do we get the max, do we multiply?

Goal
* 1st line: Please change to:

Given the tile set, with the tile scores,

* 4th line: As the word is not given directly and there may be more than one new word, please change the line to:

and given the updated board with the word you have just played,

All variable names
* As the tiles may or may not be letters (e.g. there are _, 0 and 1), suggest to change all variable names to read "tile" or "character" instead of "letter".

Input
* First line: Please change "letters" (only the first one) to "characters".

* First line: Please change "alphabet" to "tile set".

* First line: Please change "necessary" to "necessarily", and delete "always".

* nbLetters following lines: Please change "a char and a number, the letters and associated score" to "a character and an integer, which is the associated score".

* nbLetters following lines: Please add "The character may or may not be a letter."

* Next line (width and height): Please add "space separated".

* Please change "letters previously given" to "characters in the tile set" (twice).

Output
* Please format "Bonus 50" as a {{constant}}.

* Please change "new letters" to "new tiles".

* Please format "Total" as a {{constant}} instead of a [[variable]].

* Please change "with the total" to "followed by a space and the total".

Constraints
* Please change "new letters" to "new tiles" (twice).

* Please change "letter" to "tile" (twice).

* Please change "near an" to "near a".

Thanks.

All done, I hope I didn't forget something.
Thanks for your feedback.

I thought everyone knew how Scrabble worked^^

I'll update the statement to explain how to compute in this case, but I don't understand your substraction.

If you play the word "EXAMPLE", with P on a "L" cell and A on a "w" cell, your score is
E   X   A  M   P    L    E
1+8+1+3+3*3+1+1 = 24
Then *2 thanks to the "w" cell, so 48
If you play on 2 special cells "w", you multiply by 4 (6 if you played on a "w" and a "W" at the same time, 9 if two "W").

Congrats for doing it in C, now I have to do it too ^^
And you're right, I forgot the case with identical words. I'll change the statement (again).
That's right, let me few minutes ^^
Thank you ! :)
Thanks
Thank you. Do you want me to add another rule that I forgot ?

It is probably obvious for people familiar with the game, but at first I got wrong a lot of details, like the way to identify words to score (any longest line of characters of length 2 or more that includes 1 or more just-played tiles) and the way scoring itself works (I was wrong at first using multipliers on old tiles, and later not counting the values of old tiles).

I don't think the statement is at fault, life is just full of edge cases. But two sentences that confused me were:

1. "the word you have just played" ... "you scored by playing this word" -> because the player has not exactly played a word, the player plays one or more tiles that are part of one or more words
2. "summing up the scores of the tiles" -> I wasn't sure if this meant all of the tiles in the word or only the new ones, looking at the tests it became obvious

I wouldn't really change anything because adding more text might make it even more confusing, and going to wikipedia solved all my problems. Again, very nice puzzle. üëç
Thank you
It's done. I took the opportunity to add the Spanish version of the game, hopefully it will please Spanish players ^^

:D

I have no issues with my solution now but I would probably update this line:

"First line: the number of characters nbTiles in the tile set, usually 27 (26 letters plus blank tile) but not necessarily 27."

Maybe:

First line: the number of characters nbTiles in the tile set. This number can be at most 27 and includes English uppercase letters as well as the characters {{_}} and {{~}}.

Or even simpler even though it's never exactly 28:

First line: the number of characters nbTiles in the tile set, usually 28 (26 letters plus blank tile and tilde) but not necessarily 28.
Or I can just remove "usually 27 (...) but not necessarily 27"

That works too.

I just realized that you immediately add just below:

"The character may or may not be a letter."

So maybe it was already fine before mm.

Then again, as it is, I would expect only A..Z and _ from reading the statement / example.

Whatever floats your boat, I think it's such a small detail that it won't matter. And the tilde is tested upfront and not only in a validator so one can fix it afterwards if he had some logic only valid for _A..Z

I removed "usually 27 ...".
As you said, there is no trap in validators that is not in tests too.

You will certainly come up with something better than that haha. 

Looks good to me, the tests seem well designed and the puzzle was fun.

I will remove the link since it seems it's no longer useful.

And an upvote for the troubles :D.
Thanks for the compliments and the upvote, and no trouble, I've experienced much worse on other contributions.

The substraction is there because I already counted 1 in the "flat score".

Let's say you have two boards with the same word that contains the letter X, but different multipliers.

And let's say with no multipliers at all, the score of the word is 10.

Then if the board had a L tile under the X, I will score 12, that is 10 - 1 + 3 * 1.

Unless I'm misunderstanding something.

The clarifications seem sufficient, thank you.
You're welcome, I need comments like yours to improve my contributions.

I don't think my comment was particularly useful but thanks.

I implemented the score logic, but now I don't see why TESTS in "Count the 2 words" yields 5 and not 7.

All the letters have value 1, and the first S is placed on a L so it should be 7, no?

Ok, I think I forgot other rules because it was obvious for me.

The tiles TEST was already on the board. The special cells are "activated" only when you put a tile on it, then they are "deactivated". So the "L" under the first S of TEST doesn't count as a special cell.

Special cells count only for new tiles. I'm going to update the statement.
Thanks for playing this game and showing me missing rules ^^

Oh, makes sense.

I finally passed all tests. I only needed to fix that and to sort the strings when outputting.

Great puzzle, I solved it in C thinking it was going to be an easy ride but oh man was I wrong. 200 lines and many SEGFAULTS later here we are.

I haven't double checked the statement but this are my very minor remarks:

- "The score is calculated by first summing up the scores of the tiles. If any tile falls on l/L, the score of that tile is doubled/tripled before summing up. After the sum is found, apply the w/W multipliers to the sum if any tile falls on those cells, and you get the final score.
If you play on several w or W, the multipliers are applied successively.

Note that special cells are effective only for new tiles, they aren't for tiles previously played."

>> Maybe the note is not needed if you add a played here:

"The score is calculated by first summing up the scores of the tiles. If any JUST PLAYED tile falls on l/L, the score of that tile is doubled/tripled before summing up. After the sum is found, apply the w/W multipliers to the sum if any JUST PLAYED tile falls on those cells, and you get the final score.
If you play on several w or W, the multipliers are applied successively.

(NO NOTE)"

without caps, these I added for visibility.

- The references should probably be at the bottom? (And now that you explained everything maybe they are not even necessary? in case you want to golf the statement :P)

--

Also I think my solution should not be valid, I will try to post once I find a counterexample.

Thanks :)
No I don't want to golf the statement ^^ just make it "not oversized".
Why do you think your solution shouldn't work ?

Good job, just one thing missing ü§™

Constraints
* Please change "nbLetters" to "nbTiles".

Thank you!
I updated the statement after Rafa's comment, can you check about english mistakes please ?

My pleasure! Here we go:

* Suggest to delete "with multipliers" in the heading.

* Suggest to delete "(i.e. sum of tiles, after multiplying by l or L)".

* Suggest to add the following above "If you play on‚Ä¶":

The score is calculated by first summing up the scores of the tiles. If any tile falls on {{l}}/{{L}}, the score of that tile is doubled/tripled before summing up. After the sum is found, apply the {{w}}/{{W}} multipliers to the sum if any tile falls on those cells, and you get the final score.

* Suggest to change "they multiply among themselves" to "the multipliers are applied successively".

* Please fix the typo: "enought" => "enough".

* Suggest to change "these examples" to "how scoring works in practice".

Thanks.
Thank you very much :)

Goal
* Please change "any just played tile" to "any tile just played".

Thanks.
Done !

I've just realised that there are non-letter characters in the output words, so "alphabetical order" (Output section) may not be necessarily applicable. "Lexicographical order" may be a more accurate term to cover those cases.
Done. But actually it doesn't matter, there are enough real letters when you need to sort.
I was thinking of specifically the last pair of cases.
